Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Theoretical Framework for the Conceptual Design of Compliant Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to provide a theoretical framework for advancing the state-of-art of the conceptual design of compliant systems. The goal of this work is to (i) develop a kinetostatic synthesis theory for the concept generation of compliant mechanisms, (ii) gain a fundamental understanding of compliant mechanism design problems by seeking their entire solution via computational algorithms based on globally convergent polynomial solvers, and (iii) explore the use of virtual reality (VR) environments for the interactive design of compliant mechanisms. The educational objective is to stimulate the interests of K-12, undergraduate and graduate students in learning engineering subjects through the introduction of virtual reality to different levels of design courses, an Innovation Challenge summer course, and a unique Virtual Reality Demo Day program.

If successful, this research will result in a set of conceptual design tools that overcome the shortfalls of existing approaches and enable the automatic function-to-form transformation in the design of compliant mechanisms. These tools will increase the ability of industry to design high performance compliant machine devices used in the fields of manufacturing, robotics, automobile and defense etc. This in turn will help the U.S. maintain its economic leadership and sustain its share of high-technology jobs. The proposed educational program will change the stereotypical image of engineers in young children, attract more high school students pursuing degrees in engineering disciplines and educate globally competent design engineers for industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merits:

In this project, PI and his research team have developed a novel advanced computational method and modeling tools for design of compliant mechanisms by leveraging high performance computer power. The modeling tool features small approximation error and quick calculation of deformation of compliant mechanisms. The method has already been implemented in the form of computational tools and software package which enable design engineers rapidly explore the design space for the best solution for a specific task. This design framework o the shortfalls of existing approaches and fill the knowledge gap between the research fields of rigid-body mechanisms and compliant mechanisms. The result is a set of conceptual design tools which achieve an automatic transformation from function-to-form for compliant mechanisms. 

These theoretical models and computational tools have already been applied to solve practical engineering problems that puzzle mechanical engineers for a long time. For instance, an open synthesis problem (froward kinematics analysis of compliant Steward platform) has been successfully solved using this approach. Moreover, we have developed a kinematic model for calibration and control of a highly complex nanopositioner. Using our model, we have demonstrated that the controller error has been significantly reduced. 

Broader impact: 

The conceptual design tool resulted from this project will increase the ability of industry to design high performance compliant machine devices that are inexpensive to manufacture and consume less energy to function, hence help the U.S. maintain its economic leadership and sustain its share of high-technology jobs. Compliant mechanisms have been widely used in numerous mechanical devices such as defense and medical devices. Hence this result contribute to improve the public health and national security. The new course developed from this project will change the students thinking on engineering design and produce for industry competent engineers with a better ability of approaching and solving design problems. The research outcomes have been presented in multiple national and international conferences in order to disseminate them to a broader research community as well as the industry. Also a tutorial on compliant mechanism design has been planned and will be offered in an international conference 2015.

The educational outreach activities conducted at The Ohio State University and University of Maryland Baltimore County helped to improve the stereotypical image of engineers in the minds of middle/high school students and the broader public. We hope to attract more high school students in particular woman and minority students pursuing degrees in engineering disciplines.
